{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3076998,"name":"Gabriel Tibbitts","username":"Lezien","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-08-13T20:39:29.512Z","cooked":"

My team commonly uses 1/2-inch aluminum churros as shafts or 1/2-inch hexes. We have a lot of trouble going from the output shaft of our motors which are typically 8mm or 10mm circles to the churro or hex. We were wondering how teams commonly get around that. Are there adapters or couplers that can be bought? So that we can attach our motor output to a churro.

I have seen there are gearboxes that output to hex or churro but I was wondering if teams anytime they need to go from standard output to churro just use a gearbox to convert even if the motors stats are sufficient for the use or if there is a cheap and/or simple solution to mate them.

We have 3d printed 8mm to hex/churro adapters so we could attach a churro axle to our motors but they are only so strong and have broken in some instances. So their reliability isn’t great.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-08-13T20:39:29.512Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":816,"reads":358,"readers_count":357,"score":4166.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":414131,"topic_slug":"driving-a-1-2-inch-churro-or-hex","display_username":"Gabriel Tibbitts","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53639,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/driving-a-1-2-inch-churro-or-hex/414131/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3076999,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2022-08-13T21:00:10.047Z","cooked":"

Generally all the motors on our robot have a pulley, pinion gear, or planetary gearbox on the output. This works out great for us, but almost all parts on our robots are cut with a CNC, so this won’t work for all teams.

Some other solutions that we used before we got a CNC:

Attaching 2 Andymark hubs bolted together works alright. You will need some spacers between them (washers will probably work). You have to be super careful with alignment of the motor to the shaft. I’ve thought before that maybe using rubber grommets or TPU 3D printed spacers between the two hubs would help correct for some misalignment, but I have never attempted this. This is a pretty bulky and heavy solution, but it’s strong.

For short hex output, there are adapters available from Andymark and Rev. You could then go through and add an Andymark Hex coupler to make the output as long as you want. Be careful though, as there isn’t going to be anything holding the hex shaft on the motor axially, so you will need to find another way to secure it, like a couple e clips, or shaft collars.

Another method if you are set on a 1:1 ratio is to use the Rev MAXPlanetary system in a 1:1 configuration. You will have to cut the Neo/Cim/Falcon shaft for this configuration. You then could use the Rev Rounded Hex as an output, and cut it to whatever length you want (up to 36").

Hope this is helpful. There are likely many other ways to do this too.

VexPro’s VersaPlanetary Gearboxes are how our team usually does this. From here you can use shaft couplers from VexPro, or gears or pulleys with belts to transfer power.

Edit: getting the distances with belts right is tricky but WCP offers a good calculator for figuring this out.

The methods that @Lexeo mentioned are all pretty the FRC ways of doing it. It’s been awhile but I think I saw someone broach a spider coupling to run an 8mm shaft to a hex.

My quick and easy method for this over the years is to bore a churro to 8mm, slot the end on a band saw and collar clamp over the slot.

IMG_20201227_1729182964000×3000 2.91 MB

Its not super difficult to drill out a short hex shaft to 8mm and broach a keyway in it. You can also do it with an end mill from the end, but that’s a little tricky to get the dimensions right.

The Thrifty Bot sells this ready to use: https://www.thethriftybot.com/bearings/QTY-4-8mm-to-1-2-Hex-Adapter-p436635306

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-08-13T21:54:30.127Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":90.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":414131,"topic_slug":"driving-a-1-2-inch-churro-or-hex","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thethriftybot.com/bearings/QTY-4-8mm-to-1-2-Hex-Adapter-p436635306","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":58}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/driving-a-1-2-inch-churro-or-hex/414131/5","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3077013,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2022-08-13T22:39:00.046Z","cooked":"
Lezien:

or 10mm circles

Just a note: the only motor in recent memory that used 10mm output is the AndyMark PG motor, and that motor is woefully antiquated in 2022. Like, 43 watts of output power per VEX testing when the state of the art even five years ago (at the time, the VEX/WCP 775pro and AndyMark RedLine) was 300+. Brushless options like the REV NEO family and Falcon 500 are reaching even higher today with quality-of-life improvements. So I’m taking this as a cue that we need to zoom out.

Which isn’t to say your instincts are bad. In 2020, we used NEO motors with 8mm-to-1/2"-hex adapters and 1/2" hex couplers like others have described to drive twin rollers to eject balls into the lower port. We specced the NEO because it was a very short motor that could sit right on the side safely inside the frame perimeter and output enough power without a gearbox. So it is doable, but the NEO (and maybe the longer Falcon 500) is kind of a unique case in modern robots.

The long-term fix is to invest in planetary gearboxes, then transmit the power using chain or belts. Doing this provides a few key advantages:

  • Your mechanisms can be made wider, since the motor and gearbox can be flipped inboard.
  • Your motors and gearboxes can be put in a safer place from robot contact and/or in a place that improves your center of gravity.
  • Your motors can be geared closer to the ideal speed for the system without relying on massive/unobtanium pulleys.
  • By designing for the gearbox output as a mounting interface, you can be motor- and ratio-agnostic.

In 2022, there are two options that we’ve settled on going forward: the REV UltraPlanetary (for our NEO 550 motors) and the REV MAXPlanetary (for NEOs in our case, but you could totally use a RedLine or 775pro if you don’t have budget to upgrade to brushless right now). The UltraPlanetary mounts up easily using the Thrifty Motor Megaplate, while the brackets from AndyMark/REV/VEX/Thrifty Bot will accept the MAX Planetary mounting just fine (because it’s the same bolt circle and screw sizes as the CIM). We kept making foolish choices elsewhere with our MAX Planetary-powered mechanisms this year, but we gave one to our friends on 2815 to bail them out when a different gearbox was acting up and they’ve decreed them to be their future. The UltraPlanetary served us great as an intake and conveyor motor in 2021 and 2022; they’re tiny and a great price.

Two other options worth mentioning are the VEX VersaPlanetary (introduced for 2013) and the AndyMark 57 Sport (introduced for 2018). VEX pioneered this kind of gearbox, and the Sports were capable of higher output loads at a lower price if you were okay with a set ratio. For my money, the MAXPlanetary is better than both–but these can get the job done and a team in a cash crunch may be able to scrounge some from a local team that’s upgrading their own stockpile.

If you want a real cheat code, this printable roller designed by 3847 is designed to clamp onto VersaRoller or anything else with a 1.25" OD. The belt profile is the same 5mm HTD belt like you see in the AM14U chassis and is widely available for cheap. Our intake roller for Championship and the off-season has been one of those rollers with the John Deere foam grip secured around it with zip ties and gaffer tape. Works like a dream, and the roller setup (whether the stock VEX examples or something using roller bearings on a dead axle inside) is going to be much more robust than Churro.

I know I just sent an unsolicited invite to drink from the fire hose, but hopefully this sparks some bigger thoughts.

FRC95 2022 Build Thread Open Alliance
Herp… I should have posted this image like a month ago. The lovely people at Rev put this together for us to avoid cutting the end of the motor shaft off or drilling the hex shaft. [image] The orange parts are what you can add to a MaxPlanetary base stage to get 1:1 with the motor and all features intact. We printed a ring gear stage for the outer orange bit and cut a section of 8mm ID rigid plastic tubing for the orange motor shaft spacer. Right now our shooter is not end-bolted into either…

This thread talks about using a max planetary at a 1:1 ratio by adding some 3d printed parts. maxes for a really rigid and easy to mount assembly with any length shaft you want.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2022-08-14T02:19:53.547Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":75.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":414131,"topic_slug":"driving-a-1-2-inch-churro-or-hex","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc95-2022-build-thread/398263/164","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC95 2022 Build Thread","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44024,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/driving-a-1-2-inch-churro-or-hex/414131/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3077045,"name":"Gabriel Tibbitts","username":"Lezien","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-08-14T03:07:11.600Z","cooked":"

Yeah, I don’t think we have any 10mm but I just put it on there to cover my basis since I know it’s out there. But yeah I did figure most teams just put a gear box on all their motors and belt or chain them to the actuation point. I talked to my coach and we will be looking into buying more planetary motors instead of just the two we have
